results.text:
ofblackened ruins, the stark walls of the churelies and hiouses rising up out ofthe ashes and
clarred timbers heaped on every side. What must it mean to the five thousand men and
women and little children who have survived a painful flight to the seacoast and have 110W
returned to their mountain home, only to find their houses sacked and burned! Tliere were
nine Christian villages whieli elustered about Kessab in the valleys below. Several of these
have been completely destroyed by tire. All have been plundered and the helpless people
driven out or slain."
a Can you imagine the feelings of the Kessab people as theyclimbed on foot the long trail
up, the monntain, and then as they came over the ridge into full view oftheir charredl andl
ruined dwellings? Their stores of wheat, barley and rice lad been burned; clothing, cooking
utensils, furniture and tools liad gone; ; their goats, eows and mules had been stolen ; their silk
industries stamped out; their beloved churches reduced to smouldering heaps. The bodies of
their friends and relatives who had been killed had not been buried. And yet the love of
home is sO strong that the people lave settled down there with the determination to elear
the debris and rebuild their houses." -Extraets from c6 The Sack ofKessab," Stephen Van HE
Trowbridge.
As these sheets are going through the press there comes news offamine
at Zeitoon. The Rev. F. W. Macullum, American Missionary at Marash,
writes to the Rev. W. W. Peet, American Missionary at Constantinople, that
12,000 souls in and around Zeitoon are dying ofhunger ; they are wandering
about in rags, mixing bran and water, and cooking and eating it, if they can
get even that. Rev. Macullum adds, "The same story comes to us from all
sides. As we foresaw'all along, from now on the distress will be greatest. 3,
If50,000 were massacred, the list of those who have died and are dying
of homelessness and starvation will exceed 150,000. It is true; and the
numbers are not exaggerated. Last year the people reaped no harvest, and
this year there are no sowings.
The latest news is that Mush, a prosperous Armenian village that had
escaped the desolation of the massacres, has been plundered in a night attack
byarmed Kurds, and the villagers are now reduced to extreme distress. Before
the outbreak the Armenian patriarchal vicar at Mush hadrepeatedly appealed
to the Armenian Patriarch at Constantinople, and the Armenian Patriarch
had repeatedly appealed to the Authorities at Constantinople asking protec-
tion for the villagers of Mush as a Kurdish attack was apprehended. It is
evident that the authorities at Constantinople are unable to protect thriving
Armenian villages from Kurdish and Turkish raiders.

results.text:
of blaekened ruins, the stark walls of the ehurehes and houses rising up out of the ashes and
eliurred timbers heaped on every side. What must it mean to the five thousand men and
women and little eluldren who have survived a painful fłight to the seacoast and have now
returned to their mountain home, only to find their houses sacked and burned!  "Fliere were
nine Christian viHages whieh elustered about Kessab in the valleys below. Severat of these
have been completely destroyed by lire. All have been plundered and the helpless people
driven out or słain.”
< Can you imagine the feelings of tle Kessab people as they climbed on foot the long trail
up the monntain, and then as they came over the ridge into full view of their charred and
ruined dwełlings ? Their stores of wheat, barley and rice had been burned ; elothing, eooking
utensils, furniture and tools had gone ; their goats, eows and mules had been stolen ; their silk
industries stamped out ; their beloved churches reduced to smouldering heaps. "The bodies of
their friends and relatives who had been killed had not been buried. And yet the love of
home is so strong that the people have settled down there with the determination to elear up
the debris and rebuild their houses.” —Extraets from « [he Sack of Kessab,” Stephen Van hi.
'Trowbridge.
As these sheets are going through the press there comes news of famine
at Zeitoon. The Rev. F. W. Macullum, Americąn Missionary at Marash,
writes to the Rev. W. W, Peet, American Missionary at Constantinople, that
12,000 souls in and around Zeitoon are dying of hunger ; they are wandering
about in rags, mixing bran and water, and cooking and eating it, if they can
get even that. Rev. Macullum adds, * The same story comes to us from ali
sideś. As we foresaw all along, from now on the distress will be greatest.”
If 50,000 were massacred, the list of those who have died and are dying
of homelessness and starvation will exceed 150,000. It is true; and the
numbers are not exaggerated. Last year the people reaped no harvest, and
this year there are no sowings.
The latest news is that Mush, a prosperous Armenian village that had
escaped the desolation of the massacres, has been plundered in a night attack
by armed Kurds, and the villagers are now reduced to extreme distress. Before
the outbreak the Armenian patriarchal vicar at Mush had repeatedly appealed
to the Armenian Patriarch at Constantinople, and the Armenian Patriarch
had repeatedly appealed to the Authorities at Constantinople asking protec-
tion for the villagers of Mush as a Kurdish attack was apprehended. It is
evident that the authorities at Constantinople are unable to protect thriving
Armenian villages from Kurdish and Turkish raiders.
